label: lem-borel-image-of-the-projected-swarm-space
title: Borel image of the projected swarm space
nl_statement: If $(\mathcal X,d_{\mathcal X})$ is Polish and $\varphi:\mathcal X\to\mathcal Y$ is continuous, and $\mathcal X$ is $\sigma$-compact, then the projected image $\widehat{\Phi}(\Sigma_N)$ is Borel when $\Sigma_N\subset(\mathcal X\times\{0,1\})^N$ is Borel.

hypotheses.text: ($\mathcal X,d_{\mathcal X}$) is Polish
$\varphi:\mathcal X\to\mathcal Y$ is continuous
$\mathcal X$ is $\sigma$-compact
$\Sigma_N\subset(\mathcal X\times\{0,1\})^N$ is Borel

conclusion.text: The projected image $\widehat{\Phi}(\Sigma_N)$ is Borel

implicit_assumptions.text: The structure $(\mathcal Y, d_{\mathcal Y})$ is assumed to be a Polish space, or at least one where Borel sets are well-defined, for the conclusion to hold meaningfully in relation to the premise.

label: lem-polishness-and-w2
title: Polishness of the quotient state space and $W_2$
nl_statement: The quotient state space possesses Polishness properties, and $W_2$ well-posedness is established.

conclusion.text: The quotient state space is Polish, and $W_2$ well-posedness holds.

label: lem-validation-of-the-heat-kernel
title: Validation of the Heat Kernel
nl_statement: If the state space $(\mathcal{X}, d_{\mathcal{X}}, \mu)$ is a Polish metric measure space with a canonical heat kernel $p_t(x, \cdot)$ that has a uniformly bounded second moment, then defining the perturbation noise measure as $\mathcal{P}_\sigma(x, \cdot) := p_{\sigma^2}(x, \cdot)$ satisfies the required axioms, provided the boundary of the valid set $\mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}}$ is sufficiently regular.

implicit_assumptions.text: The 'required axioms' mentioned in the conclusion are implicitly defined elsewhere (likely Axiom of Bounded Second Moment of Perturbation and Axiom of Boundary Regularity, as referenced in the proof).
The meaning of 'sufficiently regular' boundary implies conditions under which the death probability integral yields Hölder continuity.

steps.text: Axiom of Bounded Second Moment of Perturbation: The definition of the state space requires that the heat kernel has a uniformly bounded second moment, i.e., $\sup_{x \in \mathcal{X}} \mathbb{E}_{x' \sim p_t(x, \cdot)} [ d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(x'), \varphi(x))^2 ] \le M_{\text{pert}}^2$. This directly satisfies the axiom.

Axiom of Boundary Regularity: The death probability is given by the function $P(s_{\text{out}}=0 | x) = \int_{\mathcal{X} \setminus \mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}}} p_{\sigma^2}(x, dx')$. This is the convolution of the indicator function of the invalid set with the heat kernel. For non-pathological boundaries (e.g., boundaries that are not space-filling curves), the heat kernel is a well-known smoothing operator. Standard results in analysis show that the convolution of a smooth kernel with an indicator function results in a continuous function. For heat kernels specifically, the resulting function $P$ is smooth and therefore locally Hölder continuous. Global Hölder continuity follows on compact subsets of $\mathcal X$ by a finite subcover argument.

label: lem-validation-of-the-uniform-ball-measure
title: Validation of the Uniform Ball Measure
nl_statement: The noise measure $\mathcal{P}_\sigma(x, \cdot)$, defined as the uniform probability measure over a ball of radius $\sigma$ centered at $x$ in the state space $\mathcal{X}$, satisfies the required axioms if the boundary of the valid set is sufficiently regular. Furthermore, the death-probability map is continuous under mild assumptions, and a global Lipschitz modulus with respect to $d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}}$ can be obtained if $\mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}}$ has a Lipschitz boundary or finite perimeter, leading to the bound $L_{\text{death}}\;\le\; C_{\text{perim}}/\sigma$.

hypotheses.text: The boundary of the valid set is sufficiently regular.
The death‑probability map is continuous under mild assumptions.
$\mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}}$ has Lipschitz boundary or finite perimeter so that boundary layer estimates apply (to claim a global Lipschitz modulus with respect to $d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}}$).

conclusion.text: The noise measure $\mathcal{P}_\sigma(x, \cdot)$ satisfies the required axioms, and $L_{\text{death}}\;\le\; C_{\text{perim}}/\sigma$ holds under appropriate regularity conditions.

constraints: uniform probability measure over a ball of radius \sigma centered at x in \mathcal{X}

variables.role: Lipschitz constant for the death-probability map
constant depending on the perimeter of \partial\mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}}

implicit_assumptions.text: The state space $\mathcal{X}$ is a metric space.
The notion of "boundary" and "perimeter" are well-defined for $\partial\mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}}$ in the context of the algorithmic metric.

label: lem-boundary-uniform-ball
title: BV/perimeter Lipschitz bound for uniform‑ball death probability
nl_statement: If $E$ has finite perimeter, the probability $P_\sigma(x)$ of a uniform ball centered at $x$ intersecting $E$ is Lipschitz in $x$ with a constant related to the perimeter of $E$ and the radius $\sigma$.

hypotheses.text: $E=\mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{invalid}}\subset\mathcal X$ has finite perimeter (BV boundary).
$\mathcal P_\sigma(x,\cdot)$ is the uniform law on $B(x,\sigma)$.
hypotheses.latex: $\mathcal P_\sigma(x,\cdot)$ is the uniform law on $B(x,\sigma)$.

hypotheses.text: $\varphi$ is $L_\varphi$-Lipschitz.
Distances are measured in the algorithmic space.

conclusion.text: There exists a constant $C_d>0$ such that $|P_\sigma(x)-P_\sigma(y)|\;\le\; C_d\,\frac{\mathrm{Per}(E)}{\sigma}\, d_{\mathcal X}(x,y)$ for all $x,y\in\mathcal X$. If $\varphi$ is $L_\varphi$-Lipschitz and distances are measured in the algorithmic space, the bound implies $L_{\text{death}}\le C_d (\mathrm{Per}(\varphi(E))/\sigma)\,L_\varphi$.

constraints: Defined in terms of integral over uniform law on B(x, \sigma)

variables.role: Distance between x and y in \mathcal X
Lipschitz constant for death probability under \varphi

implicit_assumptions.text: The space $\mathcal X$ is equipped with a metric $d_{\mathcal X}$.
The volume $\mathrm{Vol}(B_\sigma)$ is well-defined and non-zero.
The perimeter $\mathrm{Per}(E)$ is well-defined.

label: lem-boundary-heat-kernel
title: Heat‑kernel death probability is Lipschitz with constant $\lesssim 1/\sigma$
nl_statement: The integral of the heat kernel over the set $E$ (denoted $P_\sigma(x)$) satisfies a Lipschitz condition with respect to the distance $d_{\mathcal X}(x,y)$ and perimeter $\mathrm{Per}(E)/\sigma$. This implies a bound on $L_{\text{death}}$.

hypotheses.text: $E=\mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{invalid}}\subset\mathcal X$ has finite perimeter
$p_{\sigma^2}$ is the heat kernel at scale $\sigma$.
hypotheses.latex: p_{\sigma^2} \text{ is the heat kernel at scale } \sigma

hypotheses.text: $P_\sigma(x)=\int \chi_E(y)\,p_{\sigma^2}(x,\mathrm dy)$

conclusion.text: $P_\sigma(x)$ is Lipschitz with constant $\lesssim \mathrm{Per}(E)/\sigma$, and consequently $L_{\text{death}}\lesssim (\mathrm{Per}(\varphi(E))/\sigma)L_\varphi$.

variables.role: function defined by integral of heat kernel over E

implicit_assumptions.text: The space $\mathcal X$ is equipped with a metric $d_{\mathcal X}$.
The set $E$ has a well-defined perimeter $\mathrm{Per}(E)$.

label: lem-empirical-moments-lipschitz
title: Lipschitz constants for empirical moments (mean and second moment)
nl_statement: The empirical mean $\mu(\mathbf v)$ and the empirical second raw moment $m_2(\mathbf v)$ are Lipschitz in $\mathbf v$ with respect to the L2 norm, with specific Lipschitz constants depending on $k$ and $V_{\max}$.

hypotheses.text: $|v_i|\le V_{\max}$ for all $i$.

conclusion.text: The Lipschitz constants for the empirical mean and second moment are $L_{\mu,M}=1/\sqrt{k}$ and $L_{m_2,M}=2V_{\max}/\sqrt{k}$ respectively.

implicit_assumptions.text: The norms considered are the L2 norm on $\mathbb R^k$.

label: lem-empirical-aggregator-properties
title: Axiomatic Properties of the Empirical Measure Aggregator
nl_statement: The empirical measure aggregation operator $M$ satisfies the axiomatic requirements, and its specific continuity constants and growth exponents can be derived.

hypotheses.text: The aggregation operator $M$ is defined such that for any swarm state $\mathcal{S}$ with alive set $\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S})$ of size $k = |\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S})| \ge 1$, and any raw value vector $\mathbf{v}$, it produces the discrete empirical measure.

conclusion.text: The operator $M$ satisfies the axiomatic requirements of [](#def-swarm-aggregation-operator-axiomatic) and its specific continuity constants and growth exponents are derived.

implicit_assumptions.text: The existence and axiomatic requirements defined in definition reference [](#def-swarm-aggregation-operator-axiomatic).
The context requires understanding of swarm states (\mathcal{S}), alive sets (\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S})), and Dirac delta functions (\delta_{v_i}).

label: lem-set-difference-bound
title: Bound on the Error from Companion Set Change
nl_statement: The absolute difference between two set sums, normalized by the size of the first set, is bounded by the product of the maximum function value $M_f$ and the size of the symmetric difference between the sets, all divided by the size of the first set.

hypotheses.text: $S_1$ and $S_2$ are two companion support sets.
$f_j = f(x_j)$ is a real-valued function bounded by a constant $M_f$ such that $|f_j| \le M_f$ for all $j$.

conclusion.text: The absolute difference between the sums over $S_1$ and $S_2$, normalized by $|S_1|$, is bounded by $\frac{M_f}{|S_1|} |S_1 \Delta S_2|$.

implicit_assumptions.text: The set difference $|S_1 \Delta S_2|$ is well-defined for support sets.

label: lem-normalization-difference-bound
title: Bound on the Error from Normalization Change
nl_statement: The absolute difference between two sums over the same set $S_2$, using different normalization constants $1/|S_1|$ and $1/|S_2|$, is bounded by a term involving the bound $M_f$ and the difference in the set sizes $|S_1|$ and $|S_2|$.

hypotheses.text: $S_1$ and $S_2$ are two companion support sets.
$f_j = f(x_j)$ is a real-valued function bounded by a constant $M_f$.

conclusion.text: The absolute difference between the normalized sums is bounded as stated.

label: lem-cubic-patch-uniqueness
title: Existence and Uniqueness of the Smooth Rescale Patch
nl_statement: For any $z_{max} > 1$, there exists a unique cubic polynomial $P(z)$ satisfying the four $C^1$ boundary conditions specified in the definition of the asymmetric rescale function.

hypotheses.text: Four $C^1$ boundary conditions specified in [](#def-asymmetric-rescale-function)

conclusion.text: There exists a unique cubic polynomial $P(z)$ that satisfies the specified boundary conditions.
conclusion.latex: \exists ! P(z) \text{ cubic such that } P \text{ satisfies the boundary conditions}

implicit_assumptions.text: The existence and uniqueness claim hinges on solving a system of linear equations derived from the boundary conditions for the polynomial coefficients.

label: lem-cubic-patch-coefficients
title: Explicit Coefficients of the Smooth Rescale Patch
nl_statement: The coefficients $A, B, C, D$ of the cubic polynomial patch $Q(s) = As^3 + Bs^2 + Cs + D$, which is the polynomial $P(z)$ defined on $[z_{\max}-1, z_{\max}]$ expressed in the normalized coordinate $s = z - (z_{\max}-1)$ where $z_{\max} > 1$, are given explicitly in terms of $z_{\max}$.

equations.latex: P(z(s)) = Q(s) = As^3 + Bs^2 + Cs + D

conclusion.text: The coefficients $A, B, C, D$ of the polynomial $Q(s)$ are uniquely determined by the boundary conditions and $z_{\max}$.

implicit_assumptions.text: The polynomial $P(z)$ is uniquely determined by boundary conditions (implied by being a 'patch' defined to satisfy some properties, though the conditions themselves are not listed here).

label: lem-cubic-patch-derivative
title: Explicit Form of the Polynomial Patch Derivative
nl_statement: The first derivative of the cubic polynomial patch $P(z)$ on $[z_{\max}-1, z_{\max}]$, expressed in terms of the normalized coordinate $s = z - (z_{\max}-1)$, is a specific quadratic function of $s$.

implicit_assumptions.text: The coefficients for the cubic polynomial patch $P(z)$ have been previously derived.

label: lem-polynomial-patch-monotonicity
title: Monotonicity of the Polynomial Patch (Fritsch–Carlson/Hyman)
nl_statement: Given specific values for the endpoints and slopes of a Hermite cubic polynomial $P$ on the interval $[z_0,z_1]$, $P$ is monotonically non-decreasing.

hypotheses.text: The interval is $[z_0,z_1]$ with endpoint values $(y_0,y_1)$ and derivatives $(m_0,m_1)$.

conclusion.text: The Hermite cubic $P$ on $[z_0,z_1]$ is monotonically non‑decreasing.

implicit_assumptions.text: $P$ is a Hermite cubic polynomial defined by the given four conditions (two values and two slopes).
$z_{\max}$ is a positive parameter, such that the secant $\Delta$ is well-defined and positive, implying $z_{\max}>0$.

label: lem-cubic-patch-derivative-bounds
title: Bounds on the Polynomial Patch Derivative
nl_statement: The derivative of the cubic patch $P'(z(s))$ on $s \in [0, 1]$ is uniformly bounded between 0 and a constant $L_P$, provided $z_{\max} > 1$.

conclusion.text: The derivative $P'(z(s))$ satisfies $0 \le P'(z(s)) \le L_P$, where $L_P = 1 + \frac{(3\log(2)-2)^2}{3(2\log(2)-1)} \approx 1.0054$.

implicit_assumptions.text: The existence and definition of the cubic patch derivative $P'(z(s))$ relies on Lemma/Definition referenced by `lem-cubic-patch-derivative`.

label: lem-rescale-monotonicity
title: Monotonicity of the Smooth Rescale Function
nl_statement: The Smooth Piecewise Rescale Function $g_A(z)$ is monotonically non-decreasing on $ℝ$.

conclusion.text: The Smooth Piecewise Rescale Function $g_A(z)$ is monotonically non-decreasing on $\mathbb{R}$.

implicit_assumptions.text: The function $g_A(z)$ is well-defined.
The term 'monotonically non-decreasing' is understood in the standard mathematical sense.

label: lem-lipschitz-constant-of-the-patched-standardization
title: Lipschitz constant of the patched standardization
nl_statement: The composition of the piecewise rescale $g_A$ and the patched standardization $z=\sigma\'_{\text{reg}}(\cdot)$ is globally Lipschitz, with its constant bounded in terms of the Lipschitz constants of $g_A$ and $z$, and the Lipschitz constant of the variance functional $L_{\mathrm{var}}$.

equations.latex: L_{g_A\circ z}\;\le\; L_{g_A}\cdot L_{z},\qquad L_{g_A}\le \max\{L_P,1\},\quad L_{z}\le L_{\sigma\'\_{\text{reg}}}\cdot L_{\mathrm{var}}.

hypotheses.text: $z=\sigma\'\_{\text{reg}}(\cdot)$ denote the patched standardization of raw values with variance floor $\varepsilon_{\text{std}}>0$.
$g_A$ be the piecewise rescale in §8.2.2.
The variance functional of the chosen aggregator is $L_{\mathrm{var}}$‑Lipschitz (see §8.2.2.10).

conclusion.text: $g_A\circ z$ is globally Lipschitz.

variables.role: Lipschitz constant of the variance functional
global Lipschitz constant of the regularized standard deviation

implicit_assumptions.text: The function $P$ is related to the patch derivative bounds.

label: lem-sigma-patch-derivative-bound
title: Patched standard deviation derivative bound
nl_statement: The global derivative bound $L_{\sigma'_{\text{reg}}}$ for the regularized standard deviation $\sigma'_{\text{reg}}(V) = \sqrt{V + \sigma'^2_{\min}}$ is $\sup_{V\ge 0}\big|\,(\sigma'_{\text{reg}})'(V)\,\big|= \frac{1}{2\sigma'_{\min}} = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{\kappa_{\text{var,min}} + \varepsilon_{\text{std}}^2}}$.

implicit_assumptions.text: The context suggests that $\sigma'_{\text{reg}}(V)$ is differentiable for $V \ge 0$.

label: lem-lipschitz-bound-for-the-variance-functional
title: Lipschitz constant of the empirical variance
nl_statement: The variance functional $\mathrm{Var}(\mathbf v)$ is $L_{\mathrm{var}}$-Lipschitz with $L_{\mathrm{var}}:=L_{m_2,M}+2 V_{\max} L_{\mu,M}$, where $\mathrm{Var}(\mathbf v) = m_2(\mathbf v) - \mu(\mathbf v)^2$.

hypotheses.text: $\mu(\mathbf v)$ and $m_2(\mathbf v)$ denote the (aggregator) mean and second raw moment computed from a value vector $\mathbf v\in\mathbb{R}^k$ over the alive set.
The moment maps $\mu(\mathbf v)$ and $m_2(\mathbf v)$ are Lipschitz in $\mathbf v$ with constants $L_{\mu,M}$ and $L_{m_2,M}$ as in §6.2.1.
$|v_i|\le V_{\max}$ for all components $v_i$ of $\mathbf v$.

variables.role: Lipschitz constant for second raw moment

implicit_assumptions.text: The analysis concerns vectors $\mathbf v_1$ and $\mathbf v_2$ in the domain where the moment maps are defined.

label: lem-single-walker-positional-error
title: Bound on Single-Walker Error from Positional Change
nl_statement: For two swarm states $\mathcal{S}_1$ and $\mathcal{S}_2$, the absolute error in the expected distance for a living walker $i$ (based on its companion selection measure $\mathbb{C}_i(\mathcal{S}_1)$) due to positional displacement between the states is bounded by the sum of its own displacement and the average displacement of its potential companions.

equations.latex: \left| \mathbb{E}_{c \sim \mathbb{C}_i(\mathcal{S}_1)} \left[ d_{\text{alg}}(x_{1,i}, x_{1,c}) \right] - \mathbb{E}_{c \sim \mathbb{C}_i(\mathcal{S}_1)} \left[ d_{\text{alg}}(x_{2,i}, x_{2,c}) \right] \right| \le d_{\text{alg}}(x_{1,i}, x_{2,i}) + \mathbb{E}_{c \sim \mathbb{C}_i(\mathcal{S}_1)} \left[ d_{\text{alg}}(x_{1,c}, x_{2,c}) \right]

hypotheses.text: Let $\mathcal{S}_1$ and $\mathcal{S}_2$ be two swarm states.
Walker $i$ is alive in swarm $\mathcal{S}_1$ ($s_{1,i}=1$).

conclusion.text: The absolute error in the expected distance due to positional displacement is bounded by the sum of the walker's own displacement and the average displacement of its potential companions.
conclusion.latex: \left| \mathbb{E}_{c \sim \mathbb{C}_i(\mathcal{S}_1)} \left[ d_{\text{alg}}(x_{1,i}, x_{1,c}) \right] - \mathbb{E}_{c \sim \mathbb{C}_i(\mathcal{S}_1)} \left[ d_{\text{alg}}(x_{2,i}, x_{2,c}) \right] \right| \le d_{\text{alg}}(x_{1,i}, x_{2,i}) + \mathbb{E}_{c \sim \mathbb{C}_i(\mathcal{S}_1)} \left[ d_{\text{alg}}(x_{1,c}, x_{2,c}) \right]

variables.role: companion selection measure for walker $i$ in $\mathcal{S}_1$

implicit_assumptions.text: The positions $x_{k,j}$ are elements in a metric space where $d_{\text{alg}}$ is the distance function.

label: lem-single-walker-structural-error
title: Bound on Single-Walker Error from Structural Change
nl_statement: The absolute error in the expected distance for a specific walker $i$ between two swarm states $\mathcal{S}_1$ and $\mathcal{S}_2$, due to a change in the companion selection measure, is bounded by a term proportional to the total number of status changes $n_c$ and inversely proportional to $k_1-1$, where $k_1$ is the initial number of alive walkers in $\mathcal{S}_1$.

equations.latex: \left| \mathbb{E}_{c \sim \mathbb{C}_i(\mathcal{S}_1)} \left[ d_{\text{alg}}(x_{2,i}, x_{2,c}) \right] - \mathbb{E}_{c \sim \mathbb{C}_i(\mathcal{S}_2)} \left[ d_{\text{alg}}(x_{2,i}, x_{2,c}) \right] \right| \le \frac{2 D_{\mathcal{Y}}}{k_1 - 1} \cdot n_c

hypotheses.text: $\mathcal{S}_1$ and $\mathcal{S}_2$ are two swarm states with alive sets $\mathcal{A}_1$ and $\mathcal{A}_2$.
Walker $i$ is alive in both swarms ($i \in \mathcal{A}_1 \cap \mathcal{A}_2$).
The initial swarm has at least two alive walkers, $k_1=|\mathcal{A}_1| \ge 2$.
The walker positions $\mathbf{x}_2$ from the second swarm are fixed for the analysis.

conclusion.text: The absolute error in the expected distance for walker $i$ due to the change in the companion selection measure is bounded by $\frac{2 D_{\mathcal{Y}}}{k_1 - 1} \cdot n_c$.
conclusion.latex: \left| \mathbb{E}_{c \sim \mathbb{C}_i(\mathcal{S}_1)} \left[ d_{\text{alg}}(x_{2,i}, x_{2,c}) \right] - \mathbb{E}_{c \sim \mathbb{C}_i(\mathcal{S}_2)} \left[ d_{\text{alg}}(x_{2,i}, x_{2,c}) \right] \right| \le \frac{2 D_{\mathcal{Y}}}{k_1 - 1} \cdot n_c

variables.role: size of alive set in S1
companion selection measure for walker i in state S

implicit_assumptions.text: The distance metric $d_{\text{alg}}$ is well-defined in the algorithmic space.

label: lem-single-walker-own-status-error
title: Bound on Single-Walker Error from Own Status Change
nl_statement: For any walker $i$ whose survival status changes between two swarm states $\mathcal{S}_1$ and $\mathcal{S}_2$, the absolute difference in its expected raw distance measurement is bounded by the diameter of the algorithmic space, $D_{\mathcal{Y}}$.

hypotheses.text: Let $\mathcal{S}_1$ and $\mathcal{S}_2$ be two swarm states.
Walker $i$ survival status changes, $s_{1,i} \neq s_{2,i}$.

conclusion.text: The absolute difference in the expected raw distance measurement for walker $i$ is bounded by $D_{\mathcal{Y}}$.

variables.role: raw distance measurement function for walker $i$

implicit_assumptions.text: The expected raw distance measurement $\mathbb{E}[d_i(\mathcal{S})]$ is well-defined for any state $\mathcal{S}$.

label: lem-total-squared-error-unstable
title: Bound on the Total Squared Error for Unstable Walkers
nl_statement: The total squared error in the expected raw distance from the set of unstable walkers, $\mathcal{A}_{\text{unstable}}$, between two swarm states $\mathcal{S}_1$ and $\mathcal{S}_2$, is bounded by the total number of status changes multiplied by the square of the diameter of the algorithmic space $D_{\mathcal{Y}}^2$.

hypotheses.text: Let $\mathcal{S}_1$ and $\mathcal{S}_2$ be two swarm states.

variables.role: status component (implied by context of summation term)
dimension/number of components (implied by summation limit)

implicit_assumptions.text: The term $\sum_{j=1}^N (s_{1,j} - s_{2,j})^2$ represents the total number of status changes between the two states (or a quantity proportional to it, given the context of the lemma title).
$d_i$ is a quantity whose expectation is taken over the walker $i$'s position/state.

label: lem-total-squared-error-stable
title: Bound on the Total Squared Error for Stable Walkers
nl_statement: The total squared error in the expected raw distance from the set of stable walkers, $\mathcal{A}_{\text{stable}}$, between two swarm states $\mathcal{S}_1$ and $\mathcal{S}_2$ (where $|\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_1)|=k_1 \ge 2$) is bounded by an expression involving the position difference $\Delta_{\text{pos}}^2(\mathcal{S}_1, \mathcal{S}_2)$ and the number of consensus elements $n_c(\mathcal{S}_1, \mathcal{S}_2)$.

hypotheses.text: $ \mathcal{S}_1 $ and $ \mathcal{S}_2 $ be two swarm states.
$|\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_1)|=k_1 \ge 2$.

conclusion.text: The total squared error in the expected raw distance from the set of stable walkers, $\mathcal{A}_{\text{stable}} = \mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_1) \cap \mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_2)$, is bounded by $12 \cdot \Delta_{\text{pos}}^2(\mathcal{S}_1, \mathcal{S}_2) + \frac{8 k_1 D_{\mathcal{Y}}^2}{(k_1 - 1)^2} \cdot n_c(\mathcal{S}_1, \mathcal{S}_2)^2$.

variables.role: size of the set of active walkers in S1

implicit_assumptions.text: The terms $\mathbb{E}[d_i(\mathcal{S})]$, $\Delta_{\text{pos}}^2(\mathcal{S}_1, \mathcal{S}_2)$, $D_{\mathcal{Y}}^2$, and $n_c(\mathcal{S}_1, \mathcal{S}_2)$ are defined in the surrounding context (likely related to stability analysis of a system or swarm).

label: lem-stats-value-continuity
title: Value Continuity of Statistical Properties
nl_statement: The mean ($\mu$) and regularized standard deviation ($\sigma'$) are Lipschitz continuous with respect to the raw value vector $\mathbf{v}$, given a fixed swarm state $\mathcal{S}$ with size $k \ge 1$ and raw value components bounded by $V_{\max}$.

conclusion.text: The mean $\mu(\mathcal{S}, \mathbf{v})$ and regularized standard deviation $\sigma'(\mathcal{S}, \mathbf{v})$ are Lipschitz continuous with respect to the raw value vector $\mathbf{v}$.

implicit_assumptions.text: The Swarm Aggregation Operator $M$ satisfies certain axiomatic properties ([](#def-swarm-aggregation-operator-axiomatic)).
The Regularized Standard Deviation Function is Lipschitz continuous ([](#def-statistical-properties-measurement)).
The $L_2$ norm is used for measuring vector difference.

label: lem-stats-structural-continuity
title: Structural Continuity of Statistical Properties
nl_statement: The mean $\mu(\mathcal{S}, \mathbf{v})$ and regularized standard deviation $\sigma'(\mathcal{S}, \mathbf{v})$ are continuous with respect to changes in the swarm structure, specifically bounded by a term involving $\|\mathbf{s}_1 - \mathbf{s}_2\|_2^2$.

conclusion.text: The mean $\mu(\mathcal{S}, \mathbf{v})$ and regularized standard deviation $\sigma'(\mathcal{S}, \mathbf{v})$ are continuous with respect to changes in the swarm structure.

label: lem-sub-lipschitz-value-error-decomposition
title: Algebraic Decomposition of the Value Error
nl_statement: The total value error vector, $\Deltaz = z_1 - z_2$, for a fixed swarm state $\mathbf{S}$ and two raw value vectors $v_1$ and $v_2$, can be decomposed into the sum of the direct shift ($\Delta_{\text{direct}}$), the mean shift ($\Delta_{\text{mean}}$), and the denominator shift ($\Delta_{\text{denom}}$).

hypotheses.text: $$v_1$$ and $$v_2$$ be two raw value vectors for the alive set.
Let $(\mu_1, \sigma'_1)$ and $(\mu_2, \sigma'_2)$ be the corresponding statistical properties.
Let $z_1$ and $z_2$ be the corresponding standardized vectors.

conclusion.text: The total value error vector, $\Deltaz = z_1 - z_2$, can be expressed as the sum of three components: $\Delta_{\text{direct}}$, $\Delta_{\text{mean}}$, and $\Delta_{\text{denom}}$.

steps.text: The error vector $\Deltaz$ is expressed as the sum of three components: Direct Shift, Mean Shift, and Denominator Shift.
The definition of the Denominator Shift (partial information given).

nl_statement: The total squared error $\|\mathbf{V}_1 - \mathbf{V}_2\|_2^2$ is decomposed into contributions from the unstable set $\mathcal{A}_{\text{unstable}} = \mathcal{A}_1 \Delta \mathcal{A}_2$ and the stable set $\mathcal{A}_{\text{stable}} = \mathcal{A}_1 \cap \mathcal{A}_2$, yielding the sum of squared norms over these orthogonal sets, which leads to the definition of expected errors $E^2_{\text{unstable,ms}}$ and $E^2_{\text{stable,ms}}$ whose bounds are provided by subsequent lemmas.

conclusion.text: The total expected squared error is the sum of the expected squared errors over the unstable and stable partitions, $E^2_{	ext{unstable,ms}}$ and $E^2_{	ext{stable,ms}}$ respectively.

implicit_assumptions.text: The expectation operation is linear.
The sets $\mathcal{A}_{\text{unstable}}$ and $\mathcal{A}_{\text{stable}}$ form a partition of the relevant index set.

title: Bounding the Output Positional Displacement
nl_statement: There is a uniform bound $M_{\text{pert}}^2$ on the expected squared displacement of a walker starting from any position $x_{\text{in}} \in \mathcal{X}$.

hypotheses.text: For any starting position $x_{\text{in}} \in \mathcal{X}$, the random variable for the squared displacement is $Y := d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(x_{\text{out}}), \varphi(x_{\text{in}}))^2$ where $x_{\text{out}} \sim \mathcal{P}_\sigma(x_{\text{in}}, \cdot)$.

conclusion.text: The constant $M_{	ext{pert}}^2$ must satisfy a uniform bound on the mean of the random squared displacement.

implicit_assumptions.text: The space $\mathcal{X}$ is well-defined.
The metric $d_{\mathcal{Y}}$ and the transformation $\varphi$ are well-defined.
The probability distribution $\mathcal{P}_\sigma$ is well-defined.
The expectation $\mathbb{E}[Y]$ is finite for all $x_{\text{in}} \in \mathcal{X}$ when the axiom is satisfied.

title: Concentration Inequality for Total Perturbation-Induced Displacement
nl_statement: The random variable $\Delta_{\text{pert}}^2(\mathcal{S})$, which is the sum of $\mathbf{N}$ statistically independent random squared displacements, must be bounded using a concentration inequality (specifically McDiarmid's Inequality) to establish a probabilistic continuity bound for the final positional displacement.

hypotheses.text: The final positional displacement depends on the random variable $\Delta_{\text{pert}}^2(\mathcal{S})$
hypotheses.latex: the final positional displacement depends on the random variable $\Delta_{\text{pert}}^2(\mathcal{S})$

hypotheses.text: The term $\Delta_{\text{pert}}^2(\mathcal{S})$ is a sum of the $\mathbf{N}$ random squared displacements of each walker.
The random squared displacements are statistically independent for a fixed initial state $\mathcal{S}$.

conclusion.text: Apply a concentration inequality for functions of independent random variables (McDiarmid's Inequality) to bound the deviation of $\Delta_{\text{pert}}^2(\mathcal{S})$ from its expected value.

variables.role: Random variable representing the total squared positional displacement

implicit_assumptions.text: The context being analyzed is related to concentration inequalities and probabilistic bounds.

steps.text: Analyze the normalized functional for clarity.

nl_statement: For any $t > 0$, the probability that the function's value deviates from its expected value by more than $t$ is bounded by an exponential decay function involving the input variations $c_i$.

equations.latex: \sup_{x_1, \dots, x_N, x'_i} |f(x_1, \dots, x_i, \dots, x_N) - f(x_1, \dots, x'_i, \dots, x_N)| \le c_i

hypotheses.text: The supremum of the variation of the function $f$ with respect to its $i$-th argument, when other arguments are held fixed, is bounded by $c_i$.
hypotheses.latex: \sup_{x_1, \dots, x_N, x'_i} |f(x_1, \dots, x_i, \dots, x_N) - f(x_1, \dots, x'_i, \dots, x_N)| \le c_i

hypotheses.text: For any $t > 0$.

conclusion.text: The probability that the function's value deviates from its expected value by more than $t$ is bounded by $2\exp\left(\frac{-2t^2}{\sum_{i=1}^N c_i^2}\right)$.

implicit_assumptions.text: $f$ is a function of $N$ variables.

The statement relies on bounds derived from Lipschitz continuity or related concentration inequalities (like Hoeffding's inequality generalized for bounded differences, as suggested by the structure $c_i$ and the exponential bound).

label: lem-cloning-probability-lipschitz
title: Lipschitz Continuity of the Conditional Cloning Probability Function (case split)
nl_statement: The Conditional Cloning Probability Function $\pi(v_c, v_i)$ is Lipschitz continuous with respect to its two inputs, satisfying $|\pi(v_{c1}, v_{i1}) - \pi(v_{c2}, v_{i2})| \le L_{\pi,c}|v_{c1} - v_{c2}| + L_{\pi,i}|v_{i1} - v_{i2}|$, where the constants are determined by worst-case bounds.

conclusion.text: The Conditional Cloning Probability Function $\pi(v_c, v_i)$ is Lipschitz continuous with respect to its two inputs, bounded by $L_{\pi,c}|v_{c1} - v_{c2}| + L_{\pi,i}|v_{i1} - v_{i2}|$.

variables.role: fitness potential of a companion walker
fitness potential of a primary walker

implicit_assumptions.text: The definition of the Conditional Cloning Probability Function $\pi(v_c, v_i)$ (from the preceding definition) holds.
The constants $L_{\pi,c}$ and $L_{\pi,i}$ are derived from the worst-case (dead-walker) bounds.

label: lem-sub-bound-sum-total-cloning-probs
title: Bounding the Sum of Total Cloning Probabilities
nl_statement: The expected output squared metric is bounded by an expression of the form $C_L V + C_H \sqrt{V} + K$, where $V$ is the initial squared displacement.

hypotheses.text: Let $\mathcal{S}_1$ and $\mathcal{S}_2$ be two swarm states.

conclusion.text: The expression for $\mathbb{E}[d_{\text{out}}^2]$ is of the required form $C_L V + C_H \sqrt{V} + K$, allowing identification of the coefficients $C_{\text{clone},L}$, $C_{\text{clone},H}$, and $K_{\text{clone}}$ from this final expression.

implicit_assumptions.text: The final step concludes the proof, implying preceding steps established the components of the inequality.

steps.text: Divide by N to get the bound on the expected output squared metric, $\mathbb{E}[d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}}(\mathcal{S}'_1, \mathcal{S}'_2)^2]$ (where the equation uses $d_{\text{out}}^2$ implicitly):
The expression is of the required form $C_L V + C_H \sqrt{V} + K$, which allows identification of the coefficients $C_{\text{clone},L}$, $C_{\text{clone},H}$, and $K_{\text{clone}}$.
